physDesc.p: This letter is seven pages long. The word Aldington is written in pencil in the top left at a forty-five-degree angle slanting upwards from left to right. The date is in the top right along with the page annotation “Mr. Aldington–[Page #]” from the second page on.

editorialDecl.p: This letter contains references to the following:

body.p: I am overcome by your book, which I think truly magnificent for the most part. I confess, I think the war poems reach a higher mark than the love poems, probably because it is almost impossible to give love adequately in words. To me this is far the strongest work you have done, and I think you have lost none of your beauty and delicacy, as you seemed to fear you had. The poems that I already know I feel about as I did before. But there are some new ones here that I had not seen before, and which I think are as fine as any of your work.

“Fatigues” I like especially. I read it the other day in a programme of war poems which I gave for a war charity. I read that and “Apathy,” and they were both exceedingly well received. I think “Apathy” is perhaps the finest poem in the book, but it is difficult to say the finest when most of the poems are on such a high level. I am also very much interested in “Trench Idyll.” I like “In the Trenches” too, and “An Earth Goddess” is exceedingly striking. I sold this last to the “North American Review,” but unfortunately discovered immediately afterward, what I had forgotten, that it had appeared in Bubb’s “Reverie.” This is too bad for of course the “North American Review” will not take anything which has already appeared. Personally, I always regret any of these little privately printed books, as they interfere so dreadfully with public printing later on, and the circulation is not large enough to make them worthwhile, but I know you have not thought so.

The love part does not seem to me so good as the war part, to be strictly honest. It is just about impossible to do, that is the amount of it. If I had a criticism it would be, not that your poems are too physical in their expression, but that for the first time in your work you have entirely obliterated the other side of love – the spiritual. Of course, they are both true, and they must both exist together in any real love, and possibly, after the trenches, the more physical side seems the most important, but I cannot help feeling that you will be somewhat misunderstood by the expression of this section. A little change here and there, a poem or two inserted to stress the love side in contradistinction to the lust side, would have made the balance truer, I think. Do not misunderstand me. I am not in the least shocked, and personally I like these poems and think them extremely strong, but I think them only the voice of half a feeling, not of a whole feeling, and I think they may create a certain undeserved hostility in some minds, which would of course be unfortunate. That you will escape by being published by Brown, as his clientèle is small and thoroughly “in the know,” but I dreamed of finding you a larger audience, and, from your letter and Hilda’s I supposed you had not already clinched with Brown, so I took the manuscript to Macmillan when I was in New York, and urged them to print it. They were most inclined to do so. Mr. Brett, the head of the firm, was extremely interested from my description. But after they had read the volume, they returned it to me saying that they thought it was one of the strongest books they had received, but that they literally did not dare to publish the poems of the second part as they stood, and as there seemed very little chance of getting you to alter this section when you were going back to the front, there was nothing for them to do but decline the volume. Had you been here I think everything could have been arranged satisfactorily. Brown does not know this, so don’t tell him.

No sooner had I got home from New York than Brown informed me that he had already sent you the contract, and had heard from you saying that you would agree to let him have the book. Therefore there is nothing more to be done about it. Brown is always so out of funds that when he accepts books he does not always print them for ages. He has had a book of Fletcher’s for a year and a half, and it has not appeared yet. My one aim was to get you into the hands of one of the established publishers, and I am awfully sorry that this could not have been done.

I do not believe that it is what one says in a poem that matters, it is the kind of light that plays over it; and I do think you played the physical rather more than most people can appreciate. I have a theory that you have been somewhat influenced in this by Lawrence, and do you mind my urging you to be careful not to let his influence go too far? He has ruined his own public by his attitude, and I am dreadfully afraid of its effect on you, particularly as it is not in the least your natural mode of speech. By this time you are sighing and saying, “Oh Lord, Puritan New England!” but you know it is not that. I suppose the real crux of the situation lies in the extreme difficulty of touching anything so sacred as the relation between man and woman without vulgarizing it. A prurient world reads vulgarity into certain expressions which do not in the least connote vulgarity. But, after all, words are a means of communication, and if one communicates something other than what one intended, I think the result might be termed “bad writing.” That is the blunder which Lawrence makes, I think. To you and me and a few people like us, he expresses exactly what he means; but those people are a handful, and it has always been so. To most people, he says something entirely different. Now you may say that you do not write for the ignorant masses, but for the cultivated few, but I do not believe you do. Only the minor poets do that. Great poetry is and must be universal, above the customs or cliques or the delight of the initiated.

You said something in one of your letters to me which gave me infinite pleasure and much food for thought. It was that the war had made you realize “the supreme importance of literature and the supreme unimportance of literary life.” The trouble with most of us, and the reason we do not develop into great poets is that the literary life catches and clips us, and we cannot see beyond it.

This is hardly a criticism, merely a suggestion. If you were here and we were going over these poems, I should suggest very few changes, merely the addition of a few more poems on a different basis. Certain changes I would suggest, and since you ask for my criticism, I am going to be bold enough to make them.

For instance, in “An Old Song” your last two lines read:
“Into uttermost hell shall I go
For sweet sin with this lady.” Now by “sweet sin” I take it that you mean that you are worshipping a human being more than the virgin, but everybody else will read it as meaning a regular debauch. I think “Sleep” out-Lawrences Lawrence. In fact, I cannot remember any modern poem that goes quite so far as this. Was that necessary, do you think. On the other hand, I think “Before Parting” is fine with the exception of “love-plaint” which I do not like. In “Nights of Love” I should leave out the dates. This I think really very important, and I hope you will write to Brown to leave them out. They seem to me a rending open of the veil of privacy which is almost painful to the reader, and in a published book creates a sort of disgust.
I hope, dear Richard, you will not mind my telling you these things. You asked me for criticism, and therefore I am taking the liberty of making these suggestions.

Your work seems to me improving steadily. The war is making all of us more real I think. I confess that I find the ivory tower much less congenial than I did. Things are too big for us to be content with the merely precious. I hate to tell people what I think of their things. I hate to tell you most of all when by any possible chance I do not like anything, for I admire your work so entirely and admire you and your attitude toward life so much that any criticism seems impertinent. Still, I know you will forgive me and if you do not like these suggestions you will not take them.

Things are absolutely drowned in war here, but there is still a great interest in poetry. I am doing a great deal of reading poetry aloud for war purposes and have found my audiences most interested and eager. If the war lasts too long of course it will kill all the refinements of life, but if it can be ended in a year or two, I think it will have done poetry an immense service. There is already less freakishness and more seriousness, more of the real stuff of poetry coming out to-day. Of course one discounts all the popular songs of the war. They are sure to exist and do not count either way. But your book is a proof to me that the war has done you good, and that when you come back and take up the business of poet again, you will be a far greater poet than you ever would have been had the war not come. Alas, suffering is the very stuff out of which poetry is wrought! I do not believe that the poet is made of sugar candy and melts at the slightest touch. If he is worth anything he is strong enough to endure, no matter what happens to him; and, after the endurance, he should be tempered to a tool capable of much.

By the way, what is the matter with Fletcher? I do not suppose you know, but he writes me the most extraordinary letters. I had a letter from him yesterday in which he informed me that he should feel obliged to break off his friendship with me because Oppenheim had written a long didactic poem which Martyn Johnson had published in “The Dial.” Fletcher thinks that because neither he nor I have had long poems in “The Dial” for Johnson to have printed Oppenheim’s, which he does not like, is an insult to us, and that if I am not willing publicly to resent this event, I can be no friend to him, Fletcher. Did you ever hear such an insane notion? What business has any one to dictate to Martyn Johnson how to run his paper? Or to James Oppenheim what poetry he shall write? It is doubtless unfortunate that Martyn Johnson prefers James Oppenheim’s poetry to Fletcher’s and mine, but I fail to see that we have any business to go on the war path because he does, and that Martyn Johnson opens his pages at all to poetry is, I think, a happy omen. I am not going to answer Fletcher at all, and I think he will forget all about it, he usually does. But the whole thing seemed to me so unbalanced and peculiar that I cannot help thinking that the strain of the war and the lack of food has upset his health. If you know anything or can find out anything I wish you would let me know.

I am sending Hilda a copy of my lecture on you and Flint and Lawrence which I gave at the Brooklyn Institute a couple of weeks ago. In it you will see how greatly I admire you. It was in preparing this lecture that I came to realize more completely what a thunderingly fine poet you are. There is nothing like preparing one of those critical lectures to show up a man’s real qualities. I am sorry to say that Flint’s work crumbled to dust as I touched it, and Lawrence’s became almost painful in its lack of variety, but yours stood up strong, refreshing, and clear. All hail to you, my friend, go on! I think there is a lot ahead of you.

Write me often: scrawls on postal cards, scraps of paper – anything. By the way, my nephew, Captain James A. Roosevelt, is sailing for France immediately. Of course I cannot tell his regiment, but I have told him about you, and if you should ever run across him, just tell him who you are, and you are sure of a friend.

div.note: It is unclear whether Lowell is talking about Aldington's Reverie: a Little Book of Poems for H.D, published by the small, private, Cleveland Ohio-based Clerk's Press in 1917, or a draft manuscript of poems that would be published as Images of War in a small, hand-printed edition by Beaumont Press (London, 1919), and later by Allen and Unwin (London, 1919) and Four Seas Co. (Boston, 1921).
